title: Things Really Do Catch Fire
material: Things Really Do Catch Fire The Hangzhou Round famously caught fire. But what is a fire, and how does it burn? Begin your exploration of this topic with the terms below: oxidization | ignition | combustion | flash point | convection fire triangle | fire tetrahedron | flame | fuel Next, explore the history of fire. Was it discovered or invented, and by whom and when? How often is this history revised? (alternate link) Discuss with your team: if someone had first come up with fire in 2024, would they have been able to patent or copyright it? (And would it have been subject to international copyright laws?) Did anyone “own” fire in a similar way in the ancient world? One way or another, people did start the fire. While fires can occur naturally, different methods—such as matches, and episodes of the Apprentice—now allow us to start them at will. Investigate historical fire-starting, from stones and flint to ants and lenses. Discuss with your team: should children be taught how to start fires—and, if so, at what age? lighter | match | lenses | hand drill | fire striker | flint & steel | safety match A fire that no one can extinguish: not Los Angeles in 2025 but a deadly weapon in Byzantine Greece. Learn the science and history of Greek fire. Would it still be a useful weapon today, and what are its closest modern-day equivalents? Be sure to study the examples of napalm, thermite, and white phosphorus. For early humans, fire was surely useful for cooking raw Macrauchenia and for fending off saber-toothed tigers—but could it also have been used to create the ancient equivalent of cartoons? Consider this research into the prehistoric use of fire as a tool for animation, then discuss with your team: is this a form of art (or entertainment) that we should be reviving today? Can you imagine other forms of storytelling that utilize natural phenomena—for instance, strong winds—in a similar way? On New Year’s Eve ___, a tragic fireworks accident killed many and maimed more in ____. Every year, those blanks can be filled in differently, most recently with 2024 and Hawaii. Though dangerous, fireworks remain popular around the world. Research their history with your team. What were the earliest fireworks—widely believed to have been invented in China—made of, and what was their purpose? When and how did they become the bright and colorful displays they are today? Discuss with your team: should they be outlawed, and, if so, is there something that could replace them in the popular imagination? Music can be explosive; it can also be about explosives. Listen to the works below to see how the creators treat fireworks in their music. Are they celebrating or criticizing them, or is it impossible to tell? What instruments or lyrics do they use to channel the feeling of fireworks? George Frideric Handel | Music for the Royal Fireworks (1749) Igor Stravinsky | Feu d'artifice (1908) Claude Debussy | “Feux d'artifice” (1913) Oliver Knussen | Flourish with Fireworks (1988) halyosy | “Fire◎Flower” (2008) Katy Perry | “Firework” (2010) If you’ve ever gone camping on a cold night, you might have gathered around a fire with your friends to toast tasty s’mores and tell tasty stories. Every so often, someone needs to put more wood in the fire to keep it from going out—they are tending it. Early towns and villages had people assigned to this task full-time, because it was much harder to restart a fire than to keep it going. Explore the mythologies that emerged in early civilizations around the idea of keeping a fire alive and well, then discuss with your team: is there anything else similar to fire that is easier to keep alive than to restart once it is gone—and, if so, who tends to it? Consider the fire-related selections below, then discuss with your team: do they treat fire literally or metaphorically, and to what end? Art Georges de La Tour | Magdalen with the Smoking Flame (1640) Jan Griffier | Great Fire of London, 1666 Paul Sandby | Windsor Castle from the Lower Court, on the 5th November (1776) J.M.W. Turner | The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons, 16 October 1834 (1835) Tsukioka Yoshitoshi | The Moon in Smoke (1886) Alberto Burri | Red Plastic (1961) Yves Klein | Fire Paintings (1957-1961) Music Joseph Haydn | Fire Symphony (c. 1760) Richard Wagner | “Magic Fire Music” (1870) Jean Sibelius | The Origin of Fire (1910) Igor Stravinsky | Suite from The Firebird (1919) Sergei Prokofiev | Winter Bonfire (1951) Jerry Lee Lewis | “Great Balls of Fire” (1957) Johnny Cash | “Ring of Fire” (1963) Vangelis | “Chariots Of Fire” (1981) Billy Joel | “We Didn’t Start The Fire” (1989) Literature William Blake | “The Tyger” (1794) Forrest Gander | “Wasteland: on the California Wildfires” (2020) Linda Hogan | “The History of Fire” (2021) Jorie Graham | “I Am Still” (2023)

additional-material.name: revised
additional-material.text:
Recent research suggests that human ancestors may have tamed fire much earlier than previously believed, with evidence indicating that this pivotal development occurred approximately 1.5 million years ago. This finding challenges the long-held view that the control of fire was primarily associated with Homo erectus around 1 million years ago. The study, which involved analyzing archaeological sites in Africa, highlights the significance of fire in human evolution, particularly in relation to cooking, warmth, and protection.

The evidence for early fire use includes charred remains and ash found at various sites, suggesting that early hominins were not only capable of using fire but also managing it effectively. This ability likely provided numerous advantages, such as improved nutrition from cooked food, which could have supported brain development and social interactions. The implications of this research extend beyond mere survival; they suggest a transformative shift in lifestyle and social structures among early human populations.

Moreover, the study emphasizes the role of environmental factors in the development of fire use. Changes in climate and habitat may have prompted early hominins to seek out fire as a resource for adaptation. This adaptability could have been crucial for survival during periods of environmental stress, allowing early humans to thrive in diverse and challenging landscapes.

In summary, the new findings regarding the early use of fire by human ancestors underscore its importance in shaping human evolution. By pushing back the timeline for fire management, this research invites a reevaluation of the cognitive and social capabilities of early hominins, suggesting that the mastery of fire was a fundamental milestone in the journey toward modern humanity.

additional-material.name: lenses
additional-material.text:
The video titled "Toy Story Sid burns a hole in Woody" features a scene from the animated film "Toy Story," which was released in 1995. This particular moment highlights the character Sid, a young boy known for his destructive behavior towards toys. In this scene, Sid uses a magnifying glass to focus sunlight onto Woody, the cowboy doll, resulting in a burn mark on Woody's fabric. This act symbolizes Sid's cruel treatment of toys, contrasting sharply with the film's overarching theme of friendship and loyalty among toys.

The scene serves as a pivotal moment in the narrative, illustrating the dangers that the toys face in a world where they are not only alive but also vulnerable to the whims of children. Woody's injury becomes a physical manifestation of the emotional and psychological trauma that toys endure, raising questions about their existence and the nature of play. The incident also emphasizes the stark difference between the nurturing environment of Andy's room and the chaotic, destructive atmosphere of Sid's playtime.

Moreover, this moment contributes to the development of Woody's character, showcasing his resilience and the bond he shares with his fellow toys. Despite the pain inflicted by Sid, Woody remains committed to protecting his friends and finding a way back to Andy. This determination is central to the film's plot, as it drives the narrative forward and highlights themes of bravery, sacrifice, and the importance of camaraderie.

Overall, the scene encapsulates key elements of "Toy Story," including the exploration of childhood innocence, the complexities of friendship, and the darker aspects of play. It serves as a reminder of the emotional stakes involved in the lives of toys, making it a memorable and impactful moment within the film.

additional-material.name: Greek fire
additional-material.text:
Greek fire was a formidable weapon developed by the Byzantine Empire, primarily used in naval warfare from the 7th to the 12th centuries. Invented by Callinicus of Heliopolis, a Greek-speaking Jewish refugee, it was designed to protect against Arab invasions. The exact composition of Greek fire remains a mystery, with speculations suggesting ingredients such as pine resin, naphtha, quicklime, and sulfur. This incendiary weapon was closely guarded, known only to the Kallinikos family and Byzantine emperors, and played a crucial role in defending Constantinople during multiple sieges.

The unique properties of Greek fire made it particularly effective in combat. It could not be extinguished by water, which intensified its flames, making it especially devastating in naval battles. The psychological impact of Greek fire was significant, instilling fear in enemy forces and forcing them to adapt their tactics. Its deployment techniques included ship-mounted tubes, portable flamethrowers, and grenades, showcasing the innovative spirit of the Byzantine military. Greek fire was instrumental in key battles, such as the First and Second Arab Sieges of Constantinople, where it helped secure the city against formidable foes.

Despite its effectiveness, the recipe for Greek fire was lost over time, contributing to its decline as new weaponry emerged. Various attempts to recreate it have failed, further enhancing its mystique. The weapon's legacy endures, influencing military tactics and strategies in subsequent civilizations. Greek fire exemplifies Byzantine ingenuity and resourcefulness, highlighting the empire's ability to innovate in the face of adversity.

In summary, Greek fire not only transformed ancient warfare but also symbolized the technological prowess of the Byzantine Empire. Its mysterious origins, devastating effects, and lasting impact on military history underscore its significance in preserving the Byzantine Empire and shaping the course of Western civilization. The stories surrounding Greek fire continue to captivate historians, ensuring its place in the annals of military achievement.

additional-material.name: a tool for animation
additional-material.text:
The article describes new research suggesting that **Ice Age artists may have used firelight to create and view carvings that appeared to move**, anticipating a kind of prehistoric animation. Archaeologist Andy Needham and his colleagues studied 15,000-year-old limestone plaquettes—small, engraved stones from the Magdalenian culture—found in southern France. These artists, who also painted the famous Lascaux caves, carved images of horses, reindeer, and other animals onto rock surfaces near their hearths. The stones show signs of heat exposure, suggesting they were intentionally positioned close to fires while being carved or viewed.

Through **experimental archaeology**, the researchers recreated similar stones, exposed them to firelight, and digitally modeled the lighting conditions of the era. They found that the flickering of flames made the engraved animals appear to move, their outlines shifting and reappearing as the light danced across the surface. This dynamic interplay between art and firelight may have been deliberate, engaging the brain’s natural tendency to perceive motion and patterns—known as pareidolia. In this way, Ice Age artists could have used the instability of light to animate their subjects, transforming still carvings into living scenes.

The team believes this artistic use of **dynamic lighting** reveals an early understanding of visual perception and storytelling. Multiple overlapping outlines of animals, seen in both carvings and cave paintings of the same culture, may have been intentional attempts to simulate movement—much like sequential animation today. The stones’ pink discoloration and burn marks suggest they were repeatedly placed around fires, not as tools but as part of communal artistic or ritual experiences.

Experts caution that not all plaquettes were treated as sacred artworks—some were later reused, broken, or discarded—but the findings illuminate how **art, fire, and social life intertwined** in Ice Age communities. Creating art by the fire may have served both spiritual and social functions, allowing groups to bond, reflect, and find meaning together at the end of hard days. As Needham put it, the practice feels “deeply human”—evidence that even 15,000 years ago, people sought not just survival but shared beauty and imagination.

additional-material.name: Hawaii
additional-material.text:
A deadly fireworks explosion in Honolulu on New Year’s Eve has reignited Hawaii’s long struggle with illegal, large-scale pyrotechnic displays. Three women were killed and more than twenty others injured—many with severe burns—after a bundle of mortar-style fireworks tipped over and ignited nearby crates, triggering a chain of explosions. Authorities described the event as one of the state’s worst fireworks accidents in recent memory. One additional person died in a separate fireworks incident on Oahu that same night. Officials are pleading for an end to amateur fireworks shows, which have become increasingly elaborate, dangerous, and ingrained in local celebrations.

Illegal fireworks have long been a contentious issue in Hawaii. They light up skies during nearly every major event—from New Year’s and Thanksgiving to sporting events—and are often defended as a cultural tradition. However, they have also caused frequent injuries, fires, and property damage. Despite bans and enforcement efforts, the displays continue to grow in intensity, thanks to a thriving black market. A state task force formed in 2023 has seized over 227,000 pounds of contraband fireworks, yet the Honolulu Fire Department still reported a 30 percent increase in fireworks-related fires this New Year’s compared to last year.

Local leaders are urging stronger action. Honolulu Mayor Rick Blangiardi called the recent explosion a “painful reminder” of the risks posed by illegal fireworks, while lawmakers emphasized that the devices now resemble “explosive bombs,” far more powerful than the small firecrackers once used in cultural celebrations. Enforcement, however, remains difficult: residents are often reluctant to report neighbors in tight-knit communities for fear of retaliation. Even when reports are made, police rarely catch offenders in the act, making prosecutions rare.

Officials are now looking to **stop illegal fireworks at the source**, focusing on ports where contraband shipments enter the islands. Hawaii’s governor, Josh Green, announced an amnesty program to encourage residents to surrender fireworks without prosecution. But many locals fear that even this tragedy will not change attitudes. As one community member noted, the explosions that once symbolized joy and good fortune have evolved into something far more dangerous—transforming a cherished custom into a recurring source of destruction and grief.

additional-material.name: Music for the Royal Fireworks
additional-material.text:
The YouTube video titled "Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks (Proms 2012)" features a live performance of George Frideric Handel's orchestral suite, HWV 351, conducted by Hervé Niquet and performed by Le Concert Spirituel at the Royal Albert Hall on July 18, 2012. This piece was originally composed for a fireworks display in 1749, celebrating the end of the War of the Austrian Succession and the signing of the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle. The performance showcases the grandeur and celebratory nature of Handel's music, which is characterized by its lively orchestration and rhythmic vitality.

The suite consists of several movements, including an overture followed by dances such as the Bourrée, La Paix, La Réjouissance, and Menuets I and II. Each movement contributes to the overall festive atmosphere, with the overture setting a majestic tone that is further enhanced by the subsequent lively and contrasting sections. The use of period instruments in this performance aims to replicate the sound of Handel's time, providing an authentic listening experience that emphasizes the historical context of the composition.

Audience reactions to the performance highlight appreciation for the historical accuracy and the skillful execution of the musicians, particularly in their use of natural brass instruments and baroque oboes. Many viewers express admiration for the beauty and majesty of the music, noting how it transports them to a different era. The performance has garnered significant attention, with millions of views, indicating its popularity and the enduring appeal of Handel's work.

Overall, this rendition of "Music for the Royal Fireworks" not only celebrates Handel's compositional genius but also serves as a reminder of the cultural significance of music in commemorating historical events. The performance exemplifies the rich tradition of classical music and its ability to evoke emotions and connect audiences across generations.

additional-material.name: Feu d'artifice
additional-material.text:
The video features a performance of Igor Stravinsky's "Feuerwerk" (Fireworks) by the hr-Sinfonieorchester, conducted by Paavo Järvi. This piece, composed in 1908, is a brief orchestral work that showcases Stravinsky's innovative style and rhythmic complexity. The performance took place at the Alte Oper in Frankfurt on February 17, 2011, and has garnered attention for its vibrant orchestration and dynamic execution.

"Feuerwerk" is characterized by its lively tempo and intricate interplay between various orchestral sections. The composition reflects Stravinsky's early experimentation with rhythm and melody, which would later culminate in his more famous works. The piece is often noted for its celebratory nature, evoking the imagery of fireworks through its bright and explosive musical language. Järvi's interpretation emphasizes the work's energetic qualities, bringing out the nuances of Stravinsky's orchestration.

The hr-Sinfonieorchester, known for its versatility and commitment to both classical and contemporary repertoire, delivers a polished performance that highlights the technical prowess of its musicians. The orchestra's ability to navigate the complex rhythms and textures of "Feuerwerk" demonstrates their skill and cohesion as an ensemble. Järvi's conducting style, marked by clarity and expressiveness, further enhances the overall impact of the performance.

This rendition of "Feuerwerk" serves not only as an artistic showcase but also as a reminder of Stravinsky's significant contributions to 20th-century music. The piece, while less frequently performed than some of his later works, remains an important part of the orchestral repertoire, illustrating the composer's early stylistic developments and his ability to capture the essence of celebration through music.

additional-material.name: Feux d'artifice
additional-material.text:
The video features a performance of Claude Debussy's "Feux d'artifice," interpreted by pianist Guillaume Coppola. This piece is part of Debussy's "Préludes, Livre II," specifically the twelfth prelude. The performance was recorded during a live concert event titled "Générations France Musique" on June 8, 2019. The concert showcases a variety of contemporary and classical music, emphasizing the evolution of musical styles and interpretations.

"Feux d'artifice," which translates to "Fireworks," is characterized by its vibrant and dynamic musical language, reflecting the celebratory and ephemeral nature of fireworks. Debussy's composition employs innovative harmonic structures and impressionistic textures, creating a vivid auditory experience that evokes visual imagery associated with fireworks displays. The piece is notable for its use of color and atmosphere, hallmarks of Debussy's style, which seeks to convey emotions and sensations rather than traditional musical narratives.

Coppola's interpretation highlights the technical demands of the piece, showcasing his skill in navigating the intricate passages and expressive nuances that Debussy requires. The performance is marked by a fluidity that captures the essence of the music, allowing the listener to experience the interplay of light and sound that Debussy intended. The video serves as a valuable resource for both music enthusiasts and scholars interested in the performance practices of Debussy's works.

Overall, this performance not only celebrates Debussy's innovative contributions to music but also illustrates the ongoing relevance of his work in contemporary concert settings. The live recording format enhances the experience, providing an intimate glimpse into the artistry involved in interpreting such a complex and evocative piece.

additional-material.name: Flourish with Fireworks
additional-material.text:
The video features a performance of Oliver Knussen's "Flourish with Fireworks, op. 22," conducted by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. This piece, composed in 1952, is notable for its vibrant orchestration and intricate textures, reflecting Knussen's unique style that blends modernist techniques with a lyrical sensibility. The work is characterized by its celebratory nature, often interpreted as a musical representation of fireworks, with bursts of sound and dynamic contrasts that evoke a sense of festivity.

Knussen's composition is structured in a way that showcases the capabilities of the orchestra, employing a wide range of instruments to create a rich tapestry of sound. The use of rhythm and color is particularly striking, as the piece transitions through various motifs and themes, each contributing to the overall exuberance. The performance captures the essence of Knussen's intent, highlighting the interplay between different sections of the orchestra and the intricate dialogues that emerge throughout the piece.

The context of "Flourish with Fireworks" lies within Knussen's broader oeuvre, which often explores the boundaries of contemporary classical music while remaining accessible to audiences. This work, in particular, serves as a testament to his ability to engage listeners through vivid musical imagery and emotional depth. The performance by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra further emphasizes the work's celebratory qualities, making it a fitting choice for concert settings that aim to uplift and entertain.

Overall, the video not only showcases Knussen's compositional prowess but also illustrates the skill and artistry of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. The performance stands as a celebration of both the music and the collaborative spirit of orchestral performance, inviting viewers to appreciate the nuances of contemporary classical music through a dynamic and engaging lens.

additional-material.name: Fire◎Flower
additional-material.text:
The official music video for "Fire◎Flower (Rerec)" features the Vocaloid character Kagamine Len and is produced by halyosy. Released on August 17, 2024, the video has garnered over 2.2 million views, showcasing a vibrant animation style that complements the song's energetic and nostalgic themes. The video is characterized by its colorful visuals and dynamic scenes, which reflect the song's upbeat tempo and emotional resonance. The animation is credited to RAHWIA, who captures the essence of summer and youth through vivid imagery.

Musically, "Fire◎Flower (Rerec)" is a reimagining of halyosy's earlier work, maintaining the original's catchy melody while incorporating modern production techniques. The arrangement features a blend of electronic and acoustic elements, including guitar, bass, and strings, which enhance the song's lively atmosphere. The lyrics convey themes of growth, nostalgia, and the passage of time, resonating with fans who have followed Kagamine Len's journey over the years. The song's upbeat nature and relatable message contribute to its appeal among a diverse audience.

The release of this re-recorded version has sparked discussions among fans, many of whom express a sense of nostalgia and connection to the character of Len, who has evolved alongside them. Comments on the video reflect a shared sentiment of growing up with the music, highlighting how the song has accompanied listeners through various life stages. This emotional connection underscores the significance of Vocaloid music in the lives of its fans, serving as a soundtrack to their experiences.

Overall, "Fire◎Flower (Rerec)" stands as a testament to halyosy's enduring impact on the Vocaloid community. The combination of nostalgic themes, modern production, and engaging visuals not only revitalizes a beloved classic but also reinforces the cultural significance of Vocaloid music in contemporary digital art and music landscapes. The video invites both new listeners and long-time fans to celebrate the journey of Kagamine Len and the music that has shaped their lives.

additional-material.name: Firework
additional-material.text:
The official music video for Katy Perry's song "Firework," released on October 28, 2010, serves as a visual representation of empowerment and self-acceptance. The video features various individuals who struggle with feelings of inadequacy and isolation, illustrating their journeys toward self-discovery and confidence. The central theme revolves around the metaphor of a firework, symbolizing the potential within each person to shine brightly and make a significant impact in the world.

Throughout the video, scenes depict diverse characters, including a young girl grappling with body image issues, a teenager facing bullying, and a couple dealing with relationship challenges. As the narrative unfolds, these individuals find strength and courage, culminating in a powerful visual display of fireworks that signifies their transformation and newfound self-worth. The imagery reinforces the message that everyone has the ability to overcome obstacles and embrace their unique qualities.

Musically, "Firework" combines pop and dance elements, characterized by an uplifting melody and anthemic chorus. The song's lyrics encourage listeners to recognize their inner strength and potential, resonating with a broad audience. The production quality of the video, enhanced by vibrant colors and dynamic visuals, complements the song's energetic and motivational tone.

The impact of "Firework" extends beyond its commercial success, as it has become an anthem for self-empowerment and resilience. The song has been widely embraced in various contexts, including LGBTQ+ pride events and motivational settings, further solidifying its status as a cultural touchstone. Overall, the music video encapsulates a message of hope and encouragement, inspiring viewers to embrace their individuality and strive for greatness.

additional-material.name: mythologies that emerged in early civilizations
additional-material.text:
The article "Keeping the Flame Alive" by Kurush Dordi explores the significance of fire in Zoroastrianism and its broader cultural implications. It begins by describing a daily ritual performed in Zoroastrian temples in Mumbai, where priests tend to consecrated flames, offering incense and reciting ancient texts. This practice reflects a universal reverence for fire found in various cultures, symbolizing both warmth and fear. The author connects this veneration to historical narratives, such as the myth of Prometheus in Greek mythology and the Aztec god Nanahuatl, illustrating how fire has been perceived as a divine gift and a transformative force throughout human history.

Dordi emphasizes the metaphysical role of fire in Zoroastrian theology, where it represents the divine essence of Ahura Mazda, the supreme being. The concept of Atash, or fire, is portrayed as a manifestation of cosmic energy that connects humanity to the divine. The article highlights the importance of mental fire, which symbolizes intelligence and the ability to discern truth from illusion. Through prayers and hymns, Zoroastrians invoke this inner illumination, seeking guidance and strength in their ethical choices and actions.

The article further delves into the rituals surrounding the consecration of fire in Zoroastrian temples, particularly the Atash Behram, which is considered the highest grade of sacred fire. The process involves collecting and purifying flames from various sources, each representing different cosmic energies. Dordi details the elaborate purification rituals, which include passing the fires through multiple pits and conducting ceremonies that invoke spiritual energies. This meticulous process underscores the belief that the consecrated fire serves as a talisman against ignorance and evil, embodying the collective purpose of humanity and divine beings to restore the world to its original state of perfection.

In conclusion, Dordi's exploration of fire in Zoroastrianism reveals its profound symbolic and spiritual significance. The article posits that fire serves not only as a physical element but also as a metaphor for inner wisdom and moral clarity. By maintaining the sacred flame, both literally and metaphorically, individuals are encouraged to cultivate virtues such as love, hope, and courage, thereby keeping their inner light alive amidst the challenges of life. The piece ultimately advocates for a deeper understanding of fire's role in connecting humanity to the cosmos and the divine.

additional-material.name: Magdalen with the Smoking Flame
additional-material.text:
"The Magdalen with the Smoking Flame," painted by Georges de La Tour around 1635-1637, is a significant work housed in the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA). La Tour, a French artist known for his unique style developed in provincial France, created this piece during a time when he was distanced from the artistic influences of major urban centers. His training, likely influenced by Jean Le Clerc, a follower of Caravaggio, is evident in the painting's focus on realism and emotional depth. The artwork measures 46 1/16 × 36 1/8 inches and is framed at 57 1/4 × 47 1/2 × 4 1/2 inches.

The painting depicts Mary Magdalen in a contemplative state, diverging from traditional representations that often place her in a grotto or depict her as an older woman. La Tour's approach emphasizes the psychological rather than the narrative, inviting viewers to engage with Mary’s emotional and spiritual experience. The composition is characterized by a balance of vertical and horizontal shapes, which directs attention to the Magdalen's introspective world. 

Key symbols within the painting include a skull, books of Scripture, and a scourge, all of which contribute to the somber mood. However, the focal point is the candle that Mary gazes upon, symbolizing enlightenment and contemplation. The candle's light, rendered with remarkable detail, serves as a metaphor for spiritual illumination, aligning with the themes of meditation and inner reflection prevalent in La Tour's work.

Overall, "The Magdalen with the Smoking Flame" exemplifies La Tour's ability to convey profound emotional states through simplicity and detail. The absence of a specific narrative allows for a universal interpretation of Mary’s experience, making the painting a timeless exploration of faith, contemplation, and the human condition. This work not only showcases La Tour's artistic prowess but also reflects the broader themes of spirituality and introspection that resonate across time.

additional-material.name: Great Fire of London, 1666
additional-material.text:
The painting "The Great Fire of London, 1666" by Jan Griffier I depicts the catastrophic event that devastated London in September 1666. This historical disaster began in a bakery on Pudding Lane and rapidly spread, consuming a significant portion of the city, including St. Paul's Cathedral. The artwork captures the chaos and destruction of the fire, showcasing billowing smoke and flames engulfing buildings, while people flee in panic. The artist's attention to detail highlights the scale of the disaster and its impact on the urban landscape.

Griffier's work is characterized by its dramatic use of color and light, which enhances the sense of urgency and despair. The composition includes various elements such as the Thames River, which serves as a backdrop, and the silhouettes of fleeing citizens, emphasizing the human toll of the fire. The painting not only serves as a visual record of the event but also reflects the broader societal implications, including the subsequent rebuilding efforts and changes in urban planning that followed the disaster.

The painting is housed in the Museum of London and measures 103.1 cm in height and 165 cm in width. It was gifted to the museum in 1927 and remains a significant piece for understanding both the historical event and the artistic representation of disaster in 17th-century England. The artwork is an important cultural artifact that invites viewers to reflect on the resilience of a city and its inhabitants in the face of calamity.

Overall, "The Great Fire of London, 1666" stands as a poignant reminder of the fragility of urban life and the enduring legacy of one of London's most infamous events. Through its vivid portrayal, the painting not only commemorates a tragic moment in history but also serves as a testament to the power of art in capturing and conveying human experiences.

additional-material.name: Windsor Castle from the Lower Court, on the 5th November
additional-material.text:
Paul Sandby’s *Windsor Castle from the Lower Court on the Fifth of November—Fireworks* (1776) captures the lively celebration of **Guy Fawkes Night**, a British festival commemorating the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605. While Sandby—an influential English artist known for his landscapes and architectural views—often focused on royal settings like Windsor Castle, this work stands out for its **emphasis on ordinary townspeople** rather than the grandeur of the castle itself. The composition draws attention to the festive crowd, bonfire, and fireworks rather than the monumentality of the architecture, making it a rare glimpse of communal life in late eighteenth-century England.

The artist’s choice of **aquatint and etching in warm brown ink** enhances the scene’s atmosphere. The reddish tone evokes the heat and glow of the bonfire, while the contrast with the white plumes of smoke from the fireworks gives the image a dynamic sense of light and movement. This interplay of tone and luminosity demonstrates Sandby’s skill in using printmaking techniques to evoke both realism and mood.

Created during a period when fireworks and public spectacles were becoming increasingly popular across Europe, the image also serves as a cultural document of how **communal celebration and national identity intertwined**. By depicting townspeople gathered in shared festivity under the silhouette of Windsor Castle—a long-standing symbol of monarchy—Sandby unites civic joy and royal presence in a single frame.

The print, now part of the **Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection**, encapsulates Sandby’s contribution to British art as both a technical innovator and a chronicler of social life. Through his attention to the glow of firelight and the energy of the crowd, he transforms a historical commemoration into a warm, human, and visually vibrant scene of eighteenth-century celebration.

additional-material.name: The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons, 16 October 1834
additional-material.text:
Joseph Mallord William Turner's painting, "The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons, 16 October 1834," depicts the catastrophic fire that consumed the British Houses of Parliament on that date. The event drew crowds along the banks of the River Thames, where onlookers marveled at the flames. The painting captures the chaos of the scene, highlighting the struggle to control the fire, which was exacerbated by a low tide that hindered firefighting efforts. Turner’s artistic interpretation emphasizes the overwhelming power of nature, as the flames are portrayed with exaggerated height and intensity.

Turner created this work in 1835, shortly after the actual event, using oil on canvas. The painting measures 92 x 123.2 cm unframed and is part of the Cleveland Museum of Art's collection, acquired through the bequest of John L. Severance. The artwork is notable for its vibrant colors and atmospheric effects, which verge on abstraction, reflecting Turner's innovative approach to landscape painting. The lower-right corner of the composition features boats moving toward the flames, symbolizing humanity's futile attempts to combat the destructive forces of nature.

The painting serves not only as a historical record of a significant event but also as a commentary on human vulnerability in the face of natural disasters. Turner's use of color and light conveys a sense of awe and terror, inviting viewers to reflect on the fragility of human constructs against the backdrop of nature's might. This duality of admiration and fear is a recurring theme in Turner's work, showcasing his ability to evoke deep emotional responses through his art.

In addition to the Cleveland version, Turner created a second painting of the same event, which is housed in the Philadelphia Museum of Art. This variation offers a different perspective, viewed from across Westminster Bridge, further illustrating Turner's fascination with the interplay of light, color, and the sublime in nature. The significance of this painting extends beyond its immediate subject, as it encapsulates the broader themes of destruction, resilience, and the human experience within the natural world.

additional-material.name: The Moon in Smoke
additional-material.text:
"The Moon in Smoke: #22 of One Hundred Aspects of the Moon" is a polychrome woodblock print created by the Japanese artist Tsukioka Yoshitoshi in 1886. This artwork is part of a series that reflects various interpretations of the moon, a recurring theme in Japanese art. Yoshitoshi, recognized as one of the last significant Ukiyo-e artists, captures a dramatic scene that juxtaposes the chaos of a fire with the serene presence of the moon, which is partially obscured by smoke. The print features a firefighter in the foreground, clad in an indigo coat adorned with decorative sashiko stitching, holding a matoi, a flag that signifies the location of the firefighting squad.

The composition emphasizes the action of firefighting, with the firefighter's squad, identified by the mark "Marugumi" on his headgear, depicted in silhouette on a roof to the right. The flames and smoke dominate the scene, while the moon, though present, plays a secondary role, suggesting a contrast between the tumult of human activity and the quietude of nature. This interplay of elements reflects the broader themes of life and death, as well as the transient nature of existence, which are prevalent in Yoshitoshi's work.

The print measures 14 by 9 ¾ inches and is classified under Asian Art, specifically within the Meiji era (1868–1912). It is part of the Yale University Art Gallery's collection, having been gifted by notable patrons including Mr. and Mrs. Fred Olsen and others in 1967. The provenance of the piece traces back to Fred H. Olsen and Florence Quittenton Olsen, who were based in Guilford, Connecticut.

Yoshitoshi's work is significant not only for its artistic merit but also for its cultural context, encapsulating the transition of Japanese art during a period of modernization. The print serves as a visual narrative that invites viewers to reflect on the relationship between humanity and the natural world, as well as the enduring influence of traditional themes in contemporary settings.

additional-material.name: Red Plastic
additional-material.text:
"Red Plastic," created by Alberto Burri in 1961, exemplifies the artist's exploration of materiality and abstraction within the context of post-war art movements. Burri, an Italian painter and sculptor, is associated with the Art Informel movement, which emphasizes the use of unconventional materials and techniques to express emotional and existential themes. This particular work is characterized by its vibrant red color and the use of plastic, reflecting Burri's innovative approach to art that challenges traditional painting methods.

The composition of "Red Plastic" is notable for its textured surface, which is achieved through the manipulation of the plastic material. This tactile quality invites viewers to engage with the artwork on a sensory level, blurring the boundaries between painting and sculpture. The choice of red not only serves as a striking visual element but also evokes a range of emotional responses, from passion to violence, aligning with the tumultuous historical context of the 1960s, marked by social upheaval and conflict.

Burri's work often reflects his experiences as a soldier during World War II, infusing his art with themes of destruction and reconstruction. "Red Plastic" can be interpreted as a commentary on the fragility of human existence and the resilience of the human spirit. The use of plastic, a material emblematic of modernity and consumerism, further complicates the narrative, suggesting a critique of contemporary society's reliance on synthetic materials and the loss of authenticity.

Overall, "Red Plastic" stands as a significant piece within Burri's oeuvre, showcasing his unique ability to transform everyday materials into profound artistic statements. The work invites ongoing dialogue about the role of materials in art and the ways in which they can convey complex emotional and philosophical ideas, making it a pivotal example of mid-20th-century abstraction.

additional-material.name: Fire Paintings
additional-material.text:
The article "Yves Klein - On Fire" discusses the influential French artist Yves Klein, particularly focusing on his innovative use of fire in his artwork. Klein, known for his vibrant blue color and avant-garde techniques, explored the concept of fire as a medium, which he believed could embody the essence of life and creativity. The article highlights how Klein's performances and artworks, such as his "Fire Paintings," challenge traditional notions of art by integrating elemental forces into the creative process.

Klein's fascination with fire is presented as a metaphor for transformation and transcendence. The article describes specific instances where Klein utilized fire, including his dramatic public performances where he would set canvases ablaze, allowing the flames to create unique patterns and textures. This approach not only emphasized the ephemeral nature of art but also invited viewers to contemplate the relationship between destruction and creation. The article underscores how these performances were not merely acts of spectacle but deeply philosophical statements about existence and the role of the artist.

The article also contextualizes Klein's work within the broader art movements of the time, such as Nouveau Réalisme and the avant-garde. It discusses how his radical methods influenced subsequent generations of artists who sought to break free from conventional artistic practices. Klein's integration of fire into his work is portrayed as a precursor to contemporary art forms that embrace performance and the use of unconventional materials.

In conclusion, the article posits that Klein's exploration of fire not only redefined the boundaries of artistic expression but also left a lasting impact on the art world. His work invites ongoing dialogue about the nature of art, the artist's role, and the interplay between creation and destruction. Klein's legacy continues to inspire artists and audiences alike, encouraging a deeper understanding of the transformative power of art.

additional-material.name: Fire Symphony
additional-material.text:
The video features a performance of Joseph Haydn's Symphony No. 59, known as the "Feuersinfonie," conducted by Andrés Orozco-Estrada with the hr-Sinfonieorchester (Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra). This symphony, composed in 1768, is characterized by its energetic and dramatic qualities, which are reflected in its nickname that translates to "Fire Symphony." The performance showcases the orchestra's technical skill and the conductor's interpretative flair, emphasizing the lively and dynamic nature of Haydn's work.

The symphony consists of four movements: the first movement, "Presto," opens with a vigorous theme that sets an exciting tone. The second movement, "Andante o più tosto Allegretto," contrasts with a more lyrical and reflective character, allowing for expressive playing. The third movement, "Menuetto – Trio – Menuetto," features a dance-like quality, typical of Haydn's style, while the final movement, "Allegro assai," returns to the spirited energy of the opening, culminating in a vibrant conclusion.

Throughout the performance, Orozco-Estrada's conducting style is noted for its elegance and precision, effectively guiding the orchestra through the intricate passages and lively rhythms. The musicians exhibit a strong sense of cohesion, particularly in the brass and woodwind sections, which contribute significantly to the symphony's fiery atmosphere. The conductor's ability to elicit a wide range of emotions from the orchestra enhances the overall impact of the performance.

This rendition of Haydn's Symphony No. 59 not only highlights the composer's innovative orchestration and thematic development but also serves as a testament to the enduring appeal of classical music in contemporary settings.

additional-material.name: Magic Fire Music
additional-material.text:
The video titled "Die Walküre - Magic Fire Music" features a performance of a key excerpt from Richard Wagner's opera "Die Walküre," which is part of his larger cycle "Der Ring des Nibelungen." This particular piece, known as the "Magic Fire Music," occurs in Act III of the opera and is significant for its dramatic and emotional intensity. The performance is conducted by Daniel Barenboim and features the Bayreuth Festival Orchestra, renowned for its association with Wagner's works and its historical significance in the opera world.

The "Magic Fire Music" serves as a pivotal moment in the narrative, where the character Brünnhilde, a Valkyrie, is surrounded by flames as she prepares to protect Siegfried. The music is characterized by its lush orchestration and thematic development, which reflects the emotional stakes of the characters involved. Barenboim's interpretation is noted for its careful pacing, allowing the music's intricate details to emerge while maintaining the dramatic urgency of the scene.

Overall, this performance of "Magic Fire Music" exemplifies Wagner's innovative approach to opera, blending music and drama in a way that continues to resonate with audiences. The video serves as a valuable resource for both Wagner enthusiasts and newcomers, offering a glimpse into the powerful emotional landscape of "Die Walküre" and the artistry of its performers.

additional-material.name: The Origin of Fire
additional-material.text:
The video features a performance of Jean Sibelius's choral work "Tulen Synty" (The Origin of Fire), Op. 32, showcasing the collaboration between the Lahti Symphony Orchestra, the Ylioppilaskunnan Laulajat Male Voice Choir, and conductor Osmo Vänskä. This piece, composed in 1902, is notable for its thematic exploration of fire's mythical and elemental significance, drawing inspiration from Finnish folklore. The performance is characterized by its rich orchestration and vocal harmonies, which reflect Sibelius's unique style that blends nationalistic elements with modern musical techniques.

Sibelius's "Tulen Synty" is structured to evoke the transformative power of fire, both as a literal force and as a metaphor for creativity and destruction. The work begins with a powerful orchestral introduction that sets a dramatic tone, followed by choral sections that convey a sense of reverence and awe towards fire. The interplay between the choir and orchestra is crucial, as it enhances the emotional depth of the narrative, illustrating the dual nature of fire as both a giver and taker of life.

Overall, "Tulen Synty" stands as an important work within Sibelius's oeuvre, reflecting his ability to capture the essence of Finnish mythology and nature through music. The collaboration of skilled musicians in this performance brings the piece to life, allowing contemporary audiences to appreciate its historical and cultural significance.

additional-material.name: The Tyger
additional-material.text:
William Blake’s **“The Tyger”** (1794) is one of the most iconic poems in English literature, a compact and mesmerizing meditation on **creation, power, and divine mystery**. Written in Blake’s collection *Songs of Experience*, it serves as a dark counterpart to *“The Lamb”* from *Songs of Innocence*, confronting the reader with the question of how beauty and terror, good and evil, can coexist within the same act of creation.

The poem’s driving rhythm and hypnotic repetition—“Tyger Tyger, burning bright, / In the forests of the night”—evoke both awe and dread. The tiger, radiant and destructive, becomes a symbol of **sublime energy**, a manifestation of the divine that defies moral or theological containment. Through its fiery imagery—“burnt the fire of thine eyes,” “what furnace was thy brain”—Blake imagines the act of creation as a kind of cosmic blacksmithing, fusing artistry, violence, and divine ambition.

Blake’s central question—“Did he who made the Lamb make thee?”—links the tiger to the lamb as dual aspects of one creative force. The poem refuses resolution: if the same Creator made both innocence and ferocity, then divinity encompasses contradiction itself. In this tension between gentleness and terror, Blake challenges the comforting binaries of Christian thought, suggesting that creation’s beauty is inseparable from its potential for destruction.

By the poem’s end, the repeated opening stanza returns, but transformed by the intervening awe and questioning. The final “Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?” no longer asks who *could* create such a being, but who *would dare*—implying courage, risk, and defiance at the heart of both artistic and divine creation. *“The Tyger”* thus endures not just as a vision of the natural world’s majesty, but as a profound exploration of the creative imagination itself—its danger, its power, and its burning mystery.

additional-material.name: Wasteland: on the California Wildfires
additional-material.text:
Forrest Gander’s **“Wasteland: on the California Wildfires”** is a visceral, shape-shifting poem that fuses ecological observation with personal reckoning, transforming the wildfire into both a literal and psychic force. Written in Gander’s characteristic fragmented, spatially dynamic style, the poem moves between the precision of natural detail and the overwhelming scope of catastrophe. It begins in quiet realism—“green spring grass… had cured / by June and by July”—and ends in apocalyptic embodiment, with the speaker merging with the fire itself, “churning, turning / the present into purgatory.”

The opening stanzas evoke a fragile California landscape drying toward ignition: brown hills crackling underfoot, larvae feeding under oak leaves, the forest alive but imperiled. Gander’s acute attention to sound—the “tinkling” of insect dust falling onto dead leaves—transforms minute ecological processes into omens of combustion. This meticulous sensory awareness grounds the poem in place even as the natural order begins to collapse.

Midway, the perspective widens into a surreal conflation of human, elemental, and cosmic imagery. The full moon “like a girl doing cartwheels” contrasts the innocence of motion with the unstoppable cycle of destruction about to unfold. Soon after, the poem’s voice fractures into the fire’s own consciousness: “I rose, swaying / and tottering on my / erratic vortex.” The blaze becomes a speaking presence—uncontrollable, self-generating, and ravenous—erasing the boundary between observer and disaster.

In its final movement, Gander frames the wildfire as a metaphor for **human perception and remorse**. “I need to turn / everything to tragedy before / I can see it,” the speaker confesses, implicating himself—and by extension, modern consciousness—in the compulsion to aestheticize destruction. The poem thus becomes both an elegy for the environment and a critique of the human desire to find meaning in ruin.

Through its jagged form and oscillation between lyric stillness and fiery possession, “Wasteland” captures the moral and emotional turbulence of the climate crisis. Gander’s language burns with both guilt and awe, showing how intimately the human psyche is entangled with the destructive beauty of the world it consumes.

additional-material.name: The History of Fire
additional-material.text:
Linda Hogan’s **“The History of Fire”** is a brief but powerful meditation on ancestry, transformation, and endurance, written in the elemental, imagistic language characteristic of her Native American worldview. The poem reimagines the speaker’s lineage as a genealogy of flame—an inheritance of heat, destruction, and renewal. Each family member is rendered as a substance or stage of combustion: the mother “a fire beneath stone,” the father “lava,” siblings “straw” and “gunpowder,” the self “smoke” and “ash.” Through these metaphors, Hogan fuses human life with the natural and the cosmic, collapsing the distinction between people and the elemental forces that shape the earth.

The poem’s tone is both elegiac and reverent. Fire, in Hogan’s hands, is not merely destructive—it is a source of continuity, transformation, and spirit. The speaker’s “dear one” is “a jar of burned bones,” yet even in death, the remnants of life sustain breath and memory. This coexistence of mortality and persistence—“and still we breathe”—reflects an Indigenous sense of interconnectedness, where energy never ends but changes form, and where grief is intertwined with reverence for what remains.

As the poem moves toward its close, Hogan widens her lens from the personal to the universal: “even the dry grass / with sun and lightning above it / has no choice but to grow / and then lie down.” The inevitability of growth, death, and return becomes the law of all living things. The poem thus reads as both an ancestral remembrance and a cosmological statement about cycles of creation and surrender.

In its final line—“Air is between these words, / fanning the flame”—Hogan turns poetry itself into an act of breath and fire. Language, like life, burns and renews; each word carries the elemental power of survival. The poem becomes a living flame—an invocation of spirit, kinship, and the continuity of existence even in the face of extinction.

additional-material.name: I Am Still
additional-material.text:
Jorie Graham’s **“I Am Still”** is a haunting, meditative poem about persistence, perception, and the search for meaning amid environmental and existential collapse. Written in her distinctive fragmented, breath-like syntax, it unfolds as a lyrical record of consciousness under pressure—an awareness that both endures and disintegrates in a burning world. The speaker stands “on the earth,” witnessing fire, drought, and disorientation, while asking fundamental questions of vision, mission, and survival. The poem becomes an act of listening to silence, of speaking to the vanishing air, and of trying to locate significance in the midst of ruin.

Images of **fire and distance** dominate: high-tension lines, stumps, and rocks burning, a horizon consumed by heat. These apocalyptic scenes mirror an inner crisis—the failure of language (“all that came out / was answers. Then nothing”) and the breakdown of human comprehension. The speaker searches for a “crease in the earth” that wind or light could enter, a path toward orientation or redemption, but finds only the dissolution of form. The natural world becomes both a mirror and a message that cannot be read, its patterns erased by destruction.

In the second half, Graham turns to **memory and invocation**. The poem’s address shifts toward the air itself—something once sustaining but now thinning and uninhabitable. She recalls a stream as an emblem of vitality and continuity, a “temple” of movement and sound, only to realize that even memory is slipping away. The voice clings to fragments of the past while acknowledging the impossibility of return. The stream—once “earth’s gift”—becomes both elegy and warning, a trace of a world that humanity failed to heed.

Ultimately, “I Am Still” is a poem about **presence within disappearance**: to be “still” means both to endure and to remain motionless in awe and grief. Graham situates the human voice on the edge of environmental and spiritual extinction, insisting on speech even as air and meaning dissolve. The poem’s final urgency—“How could we / not have heard”—echoes as both lament and call: a plea for awareness before the living world, and the language that names it, vanish entirely.
